project.name: English method editor
project.title: Editing problem-solving knowledge using a structured English paraphrase, navigation and expression composition

status.short: Work on the english editor begain in 1998 under the HPKB program. Versions have been delivered under both HPKB and the Active Templates programs. It can be run using Java on windows or unix-based systems.
status.long:
The english editor has been delivered as part of Constable, as well as under earlier projects, and can be run under windows or other operating systems using Java 1.3 or higher. A user guide that covers the english editor can be found on the Constable page.
Work on the English editor began in 1998 and is ongoing. The editor is implemented in Java and integrated with the main Expect interface. It was used in experiments conducted at Fort Leavenworth in 1998 under HPKB and in several subsequent experiments under both HPKB and the Active Templates programs. The current focus is on the expression composer, which suggests alternatives to sentence fragments based on search terms.

description.short: The English editor allows the user to examine and modify problem-solving knowledge through an automatically-generated English paraphrase of that knowledge. When users select parts of the paraphrase to modify, the editor suggests replacements, also paraphrased. The editor can also compose expressions based on search terms from the user.
description.long: Users often face a barrier in specifying problem-solving knowledge for use in an intelligent system because they are not familiar with available constructs in the language used by the system for problem-solving knowledge, or with the syntax of that language. The English method editor provides an interface for users to examine and modify problem-solving knowledge through an English paraphrase that is automatically generated from the executable specification of the knowledge in Expect. The English text has a structure that corresponds to the structure of the problem-solving knowledge, so that users can select parts of the paraphrase that correspond to sub-expressions in the specification. When a sub-expression is selected, the editor generates alternative expressions that the sub-expression could be changed to, and presents them to the user in English paraphrase. In this way the editor helps a user with both the available constructs and the syntax in the underlying language.

research.short: problem-solving knowledge, knowledge acquisition, intelligent user interfaces
research.long:
For more details on an older version of the paraphrase and alternatives generators used in the English method editor, see Blythe and Ramachandran KAW-99.
The editor includes an Expression Composer that generates compound syntactic expressions based on search terms and provides them as suggestions for the user. This is designed to help users begin with imprecise terms and choose from alternatives to find an appropriate yet precise and syntactically correct term. For examples and more details see these slides.
The editor makes use of other components of Expect's integrated UI to allow users to modify knowledge about instances, concepts and relations in concert with modifying problem-solving knowledge. At the same time the editor is able to help the user more by having the larger context of the integrated UI. See Blythe et al. IUI 01 and Blythe IJCAI 01 for more information about this synergy.
